medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient was diagnosed with Dehydrated Hereditary Stomatocytosis (DHS) due to severe perinatal edema that required pre- and post-natal ascites drainage and exchange transfusion. At puberty, he experienced intermittent lower limb edema, particularly during hot periods, which completely regressed during cold periods. After a surgical procedure for hydrocele at age 32, edema became persistent, regardless of the season, predominantly affecting the right lower limb.
medical_history.past_medical_history: Severe perinatal edema resolved after several months; mild chronic hemolysis without anemia; varying degrees of pseudohyperkalemia; moderate iron overload; underwent surgery for hydrocele at age 32.
medical_history.family_history: DHS diagnosed in four family members: the patient, his mother, and his two daughters. All affected family members had perinatal edema that resolved after several months; the patient's mother's previous pregnancy ended at 27 weeks with one twin dying in utero and the other after 1 day of life.
